Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Global Impacts of Eddies on Inertial Oscillations of the Mixed Layer
Award.AbstractNarration:
Wind-forced inertial oscillations of the surface mixed layer generate propagating near-inertial waves, which eventually break and drive small-scale mixing in the ocean interior. The importance of such small-scale mixing for the large-scale circulation is becoming increasingly apparent. However, based on the current range of estimates, the flux of energy from the mixed layer to propagating near-inertial waves may either play a major role in the ocean's power budget, comparable to the tidal input, or may be entirely negligible - a fundamental uncertainty.

This study uses data analyses, supplemented by numerical modeling, to assess the role of eddies in shaping the global character of mixed layer oscillations. The primary goal is a more accurate estimate of the global contribution of wind forcing to the near-inertial wave field. The strategy is built around accessing and interpreting the dynamical information contained in a recently enhanced dataset - the Global Drifter Program network of surface buoys, now available with approximately hourly resolution since 2005. The use of a new set of mathematical tools will capture the time-varying properties of inertial oscillations in the mixed layer, and simultaneously, those of the mesoscale eddies expected to modulate the inertial environment.

Intellectual Merit: This process-oriented study will be an important step in the larger goal of understanding and quantifying the mechanical energy budget of the ocean. It will have a direct benefit to the representation of the ocean's response to wind forcing in general circulation models, and consequently, to our ability to accurately predict climate-scale variability. Furthermore, the approach which brings together advances and expertise in data collection, analysis, and numerical process modeling will make optimal use of newly available resources and will identify outstanding areas for future research.

Broader Impacts: A primary societal benefit of this work is its potential impact on our ability to predict long-term climate variability. Funds are included to support a postdoctoral researcher, who will gain exposure to novel datasets, data analysis techniques, and numerical studies. The project will benefit other investigators by supporting and promoting the use of the high-resolution drifter dataset as a new window on ocean dynamics. Analysis algorithms developed in this work will be freely distributed to the greater scientific community, by inclusion in JLAB, J. M. Lilly's open-source software package for Matlab. The project will also fund two early career scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project was to improve estimates of the wind-driven near-inertial energy flux into the interior ocean. Towards this end, inertial oscillations recorded by NOAA's Global Drifter Program’s (GDP) satellite tracked surface drifting buoy data set were analyzed. This collaborative project involved researchers in Seattle, Miami, and London with expertise in oceanographic observations, modeling, and theory, as well as in statistical time series analysis. The strategy of the Miami component of this project was to create a data set of high-resolution hourly position fixes and velocity (first using a small subset of the drifting buoy data set), determine the best interpolation technique for operational use, and then proceed to generating a global data set using that best interpolation technique.

Efforts by the Miami group have centered on developing a global hourly drifter product from Argos and Global Positioning System (GPS) satellite-tracked surface drifters. NOAA/AOML produces and distributes the raw surface drifter data that was utilized by this project. Until this project, these data were only available as un-interpolated data or data at six-hourly intervals. The time period of interest, from 2005 to the present, corresponds to the time period when the number of operational satellites in the Argos constellation increased from 2 to 6 and the time between two consecutive Argos fixes reduced dramatically to a value between 1 to 2 hours on average. The global drifter program is transitioning to hourly GPS fixes transmitted via Iridium satellite, and the hourly interpolated product connects the pre- and post-Iridium record and characterizes how the errors have changed over time.

We then evaluated the best method to interpolate the uneven drifter position fixes to uniformly sampled hourly positions and velocities using a subset of surface drifters that have been equipped with both Argos and GPS. We evaluated errors in interpolated Argos fixes from four different interpolation schemes using the GPS fixes. These four schemes were 1) an update of the GDP’s kriging method (currently used by GDP to produce 6-hourly drifter product), 2) linear interpolation on the sphere, 3) a weighted maximum likelihood estimate (WMLE) method with the assumption of a normally distributed data, and 4) a WMLE method with the assumption of t location-scale distributed data.  Based on rigorous analysis of the location and velocity error statistics, we determined that WMLE interpolation method assuming a t location-scale distribution of the Argos locations was the best technique. The WMLE interpolation method assuming a t location-scale distribution has been applied to the GDP drifter data set from 2005 to the present.

The resulting global hourly dataset exhibits inertial, diurnal, semi-diurnal and other high-frequency oceanic motions at all latitudes, and will be used to gain a better understanding of the distribution and characteristics of high frequency motions in the upper ocean. The data set will be publically distributed on NOAA/AOML’s webpage (http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/phod/dac/dacdata.php) once the paper detailing the methodology (Elipot et al., to be submitted early 2016) has been accepted for publication.
